thread.title: For Farrell football, it's about family
thread.title_full: For Farrell football, it's about family - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: For Farrell football, it's about family
text:
Jim Bradley likens successful football teams to a family, and he's hoping to reaffirm that mindset at Monsignor Farrell this season and beyond.
"We're stressing a family atmosphere," said Bradley, the coach who graduated from the school in 1988. "When I played for Coach (Ben) Sarullo, Farrell was about a brotherhood. I've noticed the teams that turn out that way are usually successful."
Bradley, 41, was hired in February after the Oakwood school parted ways with Sarullo, who went 189-103-4 in 30 seasons. He won four championships (the last in 2000), but the Lions' last winning season was 2005 and the program had slumped to 17-34 in the last five seasons.
Bradley says he will change the program's fortunes through working-class values.
Bradley's knack for winning started in 1986 when Farrell captured the Metro Bowl Championship under Sarullo. It continued in 1991 at Ithaca College , which won the NCAA Division III title. Five years later, and with Bradley as an assistant coach, the University of Massachusetts won the Division I-AA championship.
A year ago, Farrell went 4-6, its third consecutive losing campaign, and were thumped 34-7 by Holy Cross in a CHSFL AA consolation playoff game.
Replacing a legend and his former high school coach could be a daunting task for Bradley. If so, he's not saying.
"The expectations for this program are always high. We have a bunch of hard workers and great senior leadership. So far it's been an easy transition," Bradley said.
The Lions return 12 starters, including seven on offense. Bradley has installed a multiple spread offense, utilizing one back. He'll have senior quarterbacks Paul Quadrato , who started as a sophomore but was injured last season, and incumbent Paul Barchitta .
"I'm looking for the best decision-maker (at quarterback)," Bradley said.
Defensively, expect an aggressive 4-3 alignment.
Farrell's first four games are a tough test, beginning with Saturday's opener against St. Joseph's Collegiate of Buffalo. The first assignment will be to stop Clemson-bound quarterback Chad Kelly , whose uncle Jim was a Hall of Fame signal-caller for the Buffalo Bills . That's followed by a murderer's row of CHSFL teams: St. Anthony's, Iona Prep and St. Joseph by-the-Sea.
"That's a very challenging schedule but it's always one game at a time," said Bradley, who practices law in New Jersey . "Two of those teams play unique offenses, presenting more challenges."
